column1:
Itellyounothing,"2019-09-10T11:13:27.86Z","This has so much potential......","

If you have read my other reviews you will know, I like Lego space themes including this one. So I am predisposed to enjoy this theme from the get go.
I can only give it a 4 out of 5 overall and now I shall explain why.
You kinda need two or three of them...... Or some of the other current Space theme sets.

Building experience - Quite fun. There are some nice play features to build in, including a pizza oven operated with a little technic push rod and a light brick for SCIENCE analysis of a rock. The modules are fun and hold the key to this sets promise.

Parts - I really like all the curves used for the modules. I like the shape of the Solar panels, but think the stickers are a let down with so many standard parts that could have taken the role without a print. But hey there we go. The boom that holds the panels should have been articulated at the module end but it'
column2: s easy enough to do with spares.

column1: Playability - This set can be a space station or
column2: a ground base with a smidgen of modification. The science analyser brick, little space shuttle, pizza oven, detachable satelite, four astronaut minifigs and the little robot offer a lot of variations for play. The module connections annoy me slightly as I feel they could be just a bit more flexible, but they are easy enough to move about. I am just left feeling like I will need two or three of these to really enjoy a good set up of either. So secondhand market watch out.

column1: Value for money - Well it has a few minifigs, plus many play options so it'
column2: s still good. Just not 5/5 good.

column1: Definitely a good addition. To hark back to my Lego Classic Space experience, I do like a good space/moon/Mars base, so I will probably be looking to make some mega construct from a few of these sets.....

,TRUE,4,4,4,4,4 Japanbuilder","2019-10-24T02:31:08.007Z","Fun enough but it could have been just a bit more","

So far this wave of City sets for space exploration has proved to be quite charming to my eyes. The color scheme the tools and technology and science being explored have been interesting. In addition this is the first set I will be looking at with the new modular system developed for this wave of Space related sets. Let'
column2: s see what we get with this station shall we?&nbsp

column1: The packaging is still very impressive with the box showing all of the features of the set and a shot of a real life space station on the corner. I still like this and in a way wish most City sets did something similar to inspire building and imagination.

column5: >
>

column1: We get several manuals a few bags and a sticker sheet in this set. Some of the stickers are quite large and make up the solar arrays for the station'
column2: s power unit. Be careful when applying these.&nbsp

column1: We get a very nice spread of figures here. All 4 are astronauts but 2 are in suits while the other 2 are in their crew uniforms for operating items inside the station itself. They are also 2 males and 2 females to even out the spread of the figures. The printing on the suited astronauts remains the same as we have seen thus far in the line and I personally like them both. While the white EVA suit is very similar to the 2015 suit the logo is smaller and on the front this time The EVAnsuited figure gets leg printing and orange trim. The orange suit is very nice looking and will likely be the look most associated with this wave in the future. The blue crew uniforms are excellent and can be worn by either gender. The logo printing and the details on display are very nice and fit into the overall scheme very nicely. One of the female crew also gets a double sided face with the alternate showing her with eyes closed to simulate sleep in the included bunk. Sadly the EVA suit astronaut has a face we have seen a few times already in this line.

column5: >
>
>
>

column1: The build itself involves some very large parts to make up the crew areas of the station. We get new pieces shaped into square like rings that are held to like pieces via technic pins. These are the parts that allow for the modular functions of the station to take shape.
The build is mostly bricks on top of the large pieces and should be simple for the recommended age group to assemble this with ease.
We also get a spare printed round 1x1 tile for the included robot which you can use to create another robot of your liking with.

Once assembled the finished piece is quite striking. The crew areas take up a bit of room and the window arrangement allows for some very nice doll-house like appearances but in space, which are very charming on their own. The included small shuttle craft also makes for a nice pilot area once attached to the station via the modular system and the lab with integrated light-brick is genius and looks very nice specially at night or in the dark.

column5: >

column1: The arrangement of the modules into a T section is quite nice and this is topped off with the solar arrays that power the station to the rear of the central hub. Disappointingly only one of the modules is double ended with the new modular components and this will highly limit how you can rearrange the station'
Overall it displays very nicely but again that limit with the modular set up means you may need multiple of this set to configure your station just the way you want.

column5: >
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

column1: The modules themselves are a mixed bag. We get a large module that makes up the galley to the station. This is equipped with a disc launcher to get at the included pizza piece and the shelf arrangement to the vegetable selection is cute. This module is also the only one with both ends usable for modular play, making it the most important one for the intended feature.

Aside from the light-brick the lab module is very tightly packed. You can shine the light on the Geode piece via the light-brick and even pretend to crack the Geode open as it is affixed to a hinged jumper assembly. However, the space is so tight the hinge function cannot be used with a figure inside the lab and indeed getting more than one figure in there will be a challenge.
The sleeping quarters are sparse as well with only one bunk and a treadmill in there. The fitting is not as tight as the lab but realistically only one figure can be squeezed in here at a time.
All the modules have decent sticker detail which display either on-board communications or remote calls. There is even a sticker showing communications with the included robot.
Speaking of that robot he is small and rather odd looking. I guess he serves as a mobile engine unit for pushing the modules to and fro during modular play.

column5: >
>

column1: The solar array can be detached but it only gets the one attachment point at the back of the hub assembly. Further it can use one pair of its arrays to deploy as a satellite. A fun feature if unsightly due to the technic pin.

This set given its price and limited modular options is rather a weak entry into the line in my eyes. I would advise against getting it at full price and only diving in once it is marked down a bit. The modules are finely detailed and the imaginative play has great potential but that feels squandered with only one of the modules being double sided which limits having the station essentially shaped into a T or X at any given time.

It is a decent enough play set with the included features and functions but it could have been more if all the modules including the solar array were double ended with that nice modular piece. Overall, it is a lacking set but fun enough. Get it only at a reduced price if you are interested in it.

column5: >
